keyConcepts.definition: A relatively permanent change in behaviour, knowledge, capability, or attitude that occurs as a result of experience (Ormrod, 2016)

components.CS: Conditioned Stimulus - produces response after conditioning
components.CR: Conditioned Response - learned response to CS

Little Albert.result: Baby conditioned to fear white rat

Little Peter.subject: 2 years 10 months old, feared furry animals
Little Peter.result: Successfully reduced fear through positive associations

keyConcepts.definition: Behaviours followed by satisfying consequences more likely repeated; behaviours followed by unsatisfying consequences less likely to occur

types.Positive Reinforcement: Adding pleasant stimulus (e.g., bonus for sales target)
types.Negative Reinforcement: Removing unpleasant stimulus (e.g., seatbelt stops beep)
types.Positive Punishment: Adding unpleasant stimulus (e.g., extra chores for curfew break)
types.Negative Punishment: Removing pleasant stimulus (e.g., speeding ticket fine)

keyConcepts.keyFinding: Behaviour shaped by reinforcement and punishment

Reinforcer timing.CC: Presented before response, regardless of behavior
Reinforcer timing.OC: Presented after behavior, only if specific behavior emitted

keyConcepts.definition: Animals biologically prepared to learn actions related to species survival with little training
keyConcepts.contrast: Contraprepared behaviours contrary to natural tendencies, learned with great difficulty

evidence.animals: Mineka (1980s) - rhesus monkeys quickly learned snake fears after 1-2 exposures
evidence.humans: Ohman et al. (1975) - humans easily conditioned to fear spiders/snakes, not flowers/houses

keyConcepts.definition: Learning occurs without immediate reinforcement, expressed later when reinforcer introduced
keyConcepts.concept: Cognitive maps - mental representations of environment
keyConcepts.significance: Challenges strict behaviorist view that immediate reinforcement necessary

keyConcepts.definition: Sudden perception of useful relationship that helps solve problem
Condition where individual/animal develops belief they cannot influence outcomes after repeated uncontrollable negative events, leading to passivity

connections.Classical Conditioning: Associating aversive stimulus with lack of control
connections.Operant Conditioning: Learning that actions have no effect reduces future attempts

definitions.text: Processes involved in the initiation, direction, and energization of individual behaviour
Study of all those pushes and prods – biological, social and psychological – that defeat our laziness and move us to action

keyConcepts.basedOn: Homeostasis - natural tendency to keep body in equilibrium
keyConcepts.definition: Physiological disruptions to homeostasis produce drives (internal tensions motivating organism to reduce tension)
Instincts are automatic, involuntary, unlearned patterns of behaviour triggered by particular stimuli

evolutionary.concept: Desire to pass on genes motivates love, relationships, attraction, marriage

keyConcepts.concept: People take actions to decrease or increase arousal levels
keyConcepts.optimalArousal: Motivated to maintain optimal level (varies by individual/situation)
keyConcepts.learningComponent: We learn what keeps our arousal at optimum level

keyConcepts.definition: Goal-directed behavior jointly determined by expectation that behaviors will lead to goal and incentive value placed on goal

example.highExpectancy: Consistently scored high on practice quizzes
example.highValue: Exam worth 30% of grade, aims for postgraduate program

definitions.Extrinsic: Performing activity to obtain external reward or avoid punishment
definitions.Intrinsic: Performing activity for its own sake - enjoyable or challenging

examples.Intrinsic: Student enrolls in creative writing because they love storytelling, not required for major
examples.Extrinsic: Student enrolls in creative writing because it's easy and will get good grade

components: Negatively oriented motivation to avoid failure (fear of failure)

measurement.description: Projective test - individuals shown ambiguous pictures, create stories

limitations: Measures unconscious motives (may not align with behavior)
